Subject: [Announce] New Restlet Framework and APISpark releases
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=544893253; y=BSWZuU2I_zL_n-esBsqtKH3zpIWUY9aubqQpoVHegl8zXD9mR97TxA
X-Yahoo-Profile: jerome.louvel


--001a11c13a40d9fa7104f59f3772
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

Hi all,

We have just released a *major 2.2.0 version* of our open source web API
framework, including community contributions from 40 developers. See blog
post for changes summary:
http://blog.restlet.com/2014/03/27/restlet-framework-2-2-0-and-2-3-m1-released/

Restlet Framework *2.3 Milestone 1* is also available, including support
for Java 7. Next milestones will add support for API documentation,
management and tooling, through integration with APISpark, Swagger and
other API descriptions languages. See the detailed road map:
http://restlet.org/learn/roadmap

Launched in 2005, Restlet Framework was the first framework to embody the
REST and HTTP principles as a simple client/server Java API. It is
available in 6 consistent editions: Android, GAE, GWT, Java SE, Java EE and
OSGi. It is also at the core of our *APISpark* cloud platform that recently
reached version 2.0:
http://blog.restlet.com/2014/03/11/apispark-2-0-released/

---

Beyond this announce, I would be happy to hear what you think about the
relationship between open source projects and cloud platforms for Web API
developments. Complementary or alternatives?

Thanks!
Jerome
--
http://restlet.org
@jlouvel <http://twitter.com/#!/jlouvel>

PS: sorry for those who received this email on API-Craft as well... Hard to
choose :)

--001a11c13a40d9fa7104f59f3772
